windows.symptom: fsx steam edition, toga button        I've set up the buttons on my flight simulator (HOTAS) so that button 5 is the TOGA button, but selecting that during a go-around doesn't cycle the approach mode back to LNAV as it should (767).  Is this option not supported?Thanks,
solutions: If you didn't map TOGA to HOTAS and just used the switch behind the throttle, would the desired outcome be different?  That is, the aircraft would accelerate to take off thrust and also automatically switch to LNAV?   If so, it seems that mapping the button to your stick may not work in the same manner.But if you know that mapping that action to HOTAS does work, then you may be able to find an answer from someone using that configuration at the FSX-SE Forums.Chris

Chris,Thanks for the reply.  I'm not sure which 'switch behind the throttle' you mean.The TOGA function didn't have a mapped button when I originally went into the setting menu in FSX, so I chose button 5 as what would work for me.  I'm unfamilar with the forums, I'll search that, but if you have a link that would be great.  The HOTAS stick I have is the Thrustmaster brand.Cheers,Dave

Hi Dave,TOGA switches are usually behind the throttle levers.   Now, whether they are operating/clickable on your 767(?) is unknown.   Some have the view that the real 767 does not have TOGA switches, only a GA switch, but you'll have to check that on your aircraft's modeller docs. So, if those switches are not there/inoperable, and FSX certainly does not have a mapped control for it, then I couldn't be sure that mapping that action (with the changeover from APP to LNAV) on button 5 on your stick would work either.Then there is FSUIPC:  https://flyawaysimulation.com/downloads/files/1689/fsx-fsuipc/For the FSUIPC User Guide:  http://static1.1.sqspcdn.com/static/f/1003521/25685034/1416357684727/FSUIPC4+User+Guide.pdfAs you may know, it is a module for communication by FSX with external add ons.  It is both free and payware;  the paid version allowing for mapping of keys, sticks, etc.   However, though very useful and many use it, I'm unsure whether even this will do what you require of FSX. Here's the link to the FSX-SE Forums:  https://steamcommunity.com/app/314160/discussions/And one to the Avsim forum that points to the TOGA/GA switches:  https://www.avsim.com/forums/topic/127717-ga-and-toga-buttons/Hope something helps you.Chris

ChrisThank you again. The 767 does have a GA switch on the throttle, and the sim works with the cntrl+shift+G combination, so I'm not sure why I can't map the function to the throttle button on my HOTAS. Not the end of the world, but a little frustrating. Dave

You're right Dave:  there is a key control for TOGA (under Autothrottle Engage (TOGA)) - didn't think to look at Autothrottle.   And yes, there is the option to map it onto a joystick.   So if it doesn't work on the joystick, or maybe in a limited way, then either the full mapping (i.e. use of auto throttle and switching to LNAV) is not being realized or it's not possible to do.  Or you need FSUIPC (registered) for the job.   But I would make enquiries about this before purchasing.The above may not have helped you at all, so can only suggest that you try putting your query to the fora and see if you get a useful hit.  Otherwise, I found these.   Some comments may not be useful, but worth reading to note other people's problems:https://steamcommunity.com/app/396750/discussions/0/1620600279679223631/https://www.avsim.com/forums/topic/266516-mapping-togo-to-joystick-button-fsx/https://www.avsim.com/forums/topic/390642-assign-a-joystick-button-to-toga-ngx/https://forums.x-plane.org/index.php?/forums/topic/146244-program-joystick-keys-in-the-757-v2/Chris

It looks like, from the links you sent me, that someone had success by mapping the button through the PMDG menu?  I'm not sure what or where that is located in the FSX menus.  The only control settings I have are the ones already described.  Dave

PMDG stands for Precision Manuals Development Group and they produce some very realistic aircraft.   You'd need to be using their products for that Menu to show up.   FSUIPC seems the only other option for you, but being a payware product (for your purposes) the chance of it not fixing your problem may not make it feasible to buy.  Maybe you could make enquiries at their forum after you check through their FAQs:   https://forum.simflight.com/forum/30-fsuipc-support-pete-dowson-modules/   (You would probably need to register with them or Simflight to present your problem).Pete Dowson regularly checks the site, so maybe an informed answer may be gained if your problem is explained in full.Chris
That all makes sense.  I put a question into the Thrustmaster support site as well, I'm hoping they have an easy fix.  Thanks again for your help, I'm a bit of a newbieDave

Everything seems to be fine. Except ... it's not.
solutions: Hi, Thank you for writing to Microsoft Community Forums. I understand that you get an error when using Windows Hello Face, we will look into this for you. However, in order to help you with the appropriate troubleshooting steps, please reply with the following details: Are you able to use the Camera through Camera application?When you say, “I re-installed the SSD that came with my PC with a (nearly) straight from the factory Windows and the camera works perfectly fine” were you able to use Windows Hello Face after installing the old SSD? I see that there are multiple models for Asus ZenBook Pro 14, I suggest you to help us with the exact model of the laptop that you are using. To find the details typemsinfo32 in the search bar on the Taskbar and hitEnter. Share the System Model along with System SKU.  However, you can try resetting the Windows Hello Biometric Database and check if that helps. Please follow the steps mentioned below: Press Windows key + R, to open Run dialog box.Type services.msc and click on OK.Look for Windows Biometric Service, double click on it and click onStop.Now, go to C:\Windows\System32\WinBioDatabase, take a backup of all the files inside theWinBioDatabase folder.After taking a backup of the files, delete all the files.Now, open Services by following step 1 and 2, and restart theWindows Biometric Service.Go to Start >> Settings >> Accounts >> Sign-in options and register the Face data again. Please reply with the status of the issue, we will be glad to help you further. Regards, Nikhar KhareMicrosoft Community - Moderator

windows.symptom: Windows 10 - doesn't recognize my user, even if I log into my account        When I start up my computer and I log into my account it somehow throws me into a a guest or a temporary user.  All of my documents are "gone", programs are "missing"  They are there though in my user name.  My internet history is missing.  I can open a chrome window and all of my recently viewed icons under the search area are missing.  Then I can open a new browser and it's there again.  It kind of flip flops from me being in my user to me not being in my user account.  Anyone have any idea how to fix this issue?
solutions: Chanie, this is happening much too often at the moment, you are logged into a temporary account . . .Before you do anything or move any files around Restart (not shut down) your PC 4 times, each time let your PC get to the Desktop before the next restart, this will fix this issue a lot of the time . ..Otherwise: Please open Windows File Explorer Navigate to C:\Users Do you see two user folders that look like yours? Open those folders and check inside Pictures, Documents . . . etc. and see if your files are thereIf your files are there: Create a new user profile with Admin privileges Log into the new user profile Copy all your data from the old profile to the new profile (Documents Library, Pictures Library . . . etc.)If you still have not found your files, look for a Windows.old folder on your C Drive, expand that to open the users folder contained inside - check there for your files, icons . . .etc.If you do find your files . . . etc. there, copy them out as soon as possible as Windows will remove the Windows.old folder in timeNOTE VERY IMPORTANT: Do Not copy your files into the Temporary profile you are currently in, when the situation is corrected, your files will be deleted with the Temporary Profile and will not be recoverable !!

windows.symptom: OneDrive syncing        I actually have a couple issues. My PC has 5 Users and files are stored all over the place.  Most will not be on OD, but some will.  Should I/Can I consolidate the files into one central location first?Yesterday while setting up OD on my laptop I accidently included my Music folder with 54gb.  My estimate is that it will take 3-5 days to upload everything.  Can I stop the upload process for just the music?  It looks like the upload is not in any logical order because I see a document being uploaded, then a song, then maybe a picture.
solutions: Files should not be stored 'all over the place.' Microsoft originally designed Windows with the idea that each user stores their files in their own user account, which is also known as their user profile. For example, userA would store their files like this:C:\Users\userA\DocumentsC:\Users\userA\MusicC:\Users\userA\PicturesC:\Users\userA\VideosIt's very important to follow this model, because these are the folders where Windowsexpects us to store our personal files. For this reason, these folders are never touched when Microsoft updates Windows 10. If we store our personal files anywhere else, where Windows doesn't expect them to be, our files may very well get erased when Windows is updated. This is particularly true for the semi-annual feature updates, which can and do make wholesale changes to Windows.More recently, Microsoft has (finally) joined the rest of the computing industry, which increasingly stores users' personal files online (aka, 'the cloud'.) There are very good reasons for doing this, but that's a different topic.Unfortunately, Microsoft is implementing this change in its usual, confusing, ham-fisted way, which sends users running to this forum asking 'what the ...' So here's how it works:Google (who came first) and Microsoft both have apps (applications, programs) that make it easy for us to store our personal files in 'the cloud,' which - for Google - is called Google Drive and - for Microsoft - is called OneDrive. You can think of the app as a tunnel, because that's really what it is. You drop files into one end of the tunnel - located on your computer - and they slide through the tunnel and come out the other end - the cloud.The part of the tunnel that opens into your computer is represented by a folder. For Windows 10, the folder is called - wait for it - One Drive. Thus, once you put a file into the OneDrive folder, it falls into the tunnel and comes out in OneDrive. Google Drive works similarly, as do Apple and Amazon.Now here's where it gets unnecessarily complicated: When you put a file or a folder into the OneDrive folder, the file or folder continues to appear in the OneDrive folder, which gives you the impression that it's still on your computer, except it's not - it only looks that way. In reality, it's on OneDrive. So when you make changes to that file or to that folder, you are actually making changes to the file or folder on OneDrive.This is why I personally don't bother with the OneDrive app or the Google Drive app. Instead, I upload files directly to OneDrive and Google Drive, by opening them with my web browser and dragging files onto the web page. Similarly, I work with those files and folders directly in OneDrive and Google Drive. Now there is no confusion about where my files are located.With all this as background, I will (at last!) get to your questions:1- You very definitely should consolidate your users' personal files into as few places as possible. For files that your users want to keep on the computer, store those files only in each user's personal profile. Not only does that make it easy to find them, they won't ever get erased by an update. (Which doesn't mean that you don't have to back them up anyway.)For files that your users want to keep in the cloud, store them directly in OneDrive and work with them directly in OneDrive. Microsoft makes that easy to do.If, instead, your users want to store their personal files in the OneDrive folder, it's not my place to say 'no, don't do that.' But because I don't work that way myself, I don't feel qualified to provide advice.2- There are two reasons why it's not a good idea to upload many gigabytes of data to cloud storage at one time: 1) ISPs typically provide severe caps on upload speed (for their own reasons) and cloud storage websites also apply a cap. Both OneDrive and Google Drive have buttons you can click on to cancel uploads in progress.

Thanks so much for the reply. This nightmare started at least 8-10 years ago with a hard drive with a bunch of bad sectors.  The shop I took it to decided first to partition, then because my husband couldn't find the files he wanted, the guy made both of us as users (gldn and JaciS). Then my husband took a bunch of my files (like pictures)  and copied them to his space. From there the monster just grew.  When I finally replaced that computer the shop set up another user Jaci5 ( I think it was a typo for JaciS) and copied everything from both users files into that group.  Now I have a lot of things triplicated on the computer. I just got the new laptop a couple days ago and wanted to sync the pc and laptop.  Now we are up to yesterday. Today I moved everything to SIEHLS and in doing so reorganized and consolidated.  I ended up removing over 60,000 files (including music, photos, and files in there as many as 4 times).  Now everything is neat and clean. I would now like to remove the extra users.  Also yesterday a Micosoft support person set up OneDrive, but it was wrong.  I don't want everything on the cloud.....just files I am working on so I can do stuff at lunch and not haul my computer around.  I was supposed to have a folder on my desktop called SYNC TO OD to drag and drop files in.  But when I opened it this morning my file wasn't there.  And I was over the max for the free account.  I was told to just remove files from there I didn't want on the cloud.  But every time I moved a bunch out it automatically filled the open space because it had my pictures folder select to sync.  I had to pay for extra space just so I could get caught up.I fixed my syncing folder EXCEPT with a heavy finger I grabbed the music folder instead of 3 songs.  I think right now I just need to let it do its thing and when it is done in a few days I can fix it.  Your opinion?

I fixed my syncing folder EXCEPT with a heavy finger I grabbed the music folder instead of 3 songs.  I think right now I just need to let it do its thing and when it is done in a few days I can fix it.  Your opinion?Whether you cancel the upload now or let it go on to completion is really up to you. If you want to have all those files in OneDrive, let it go on. But realize that the upload to OneDrive is using the upload bandwidth from your ISP, so there's less upload bandwidth available for other uploading that you may wish to do.I didn't get into this earlier because that post was long enough (!) but the way Microsoft has over-complicated the OneDrive app (in my view) is by making it more than just the tunnel I spoke of earlier. Instead, the OneDrive folder is supposed to be a combination of what's in OneDrive and what's on your computer. That's very confusing and causes lots of problems for people who post here.Again, this is only my opinion, but what's in OneDrive is one thing and what's on your hard drive is a separate thing. This is how Google handles Google Drive. I see no point in mixing files from separate places together.Your computer should have 3 or possibly 4 user accounts:A computer should have one (and only one) user account with Administrators permissions, for tasks that require elevated permissions. In practice, you'll rarely need to sign in to that user account.All other user accounts should be Users accounts, also known as Standard accounts or Limited accounts or whatever Microsoft decides to call them next week. So, one Users account for you and one Users account for your husband, and possibly a third users account for use by guests in your house.

You are person after my own heart!  All I want is a computer to do my work and a place to backup filez and an easy way to take my work with me when I need to.  I think I'll go back to dumping OneDrive and use a flash drive for portable files and an externak hard drive and sync me laptop and pc as backups.  It worked like that for the past 10 years.  I lost everything in a fire a year ago, but I grabbed my pc & laptop and never missed a file.
Glad that I could help.

solutions: Hi Rick Reinstalling Windows 10, whether on a new drive or not should not affect your Windows 10 activation or licencingGenerally activation problems after re-installing Windows 10 are caused by installing an Edition (Home, Pro . . etc) that does not match the previously installed editionOpen the Settings App (gear icon on your Start Menu) Go to System - About Does the edition reported there match the previously installed edition? If it does, what is the exact Activation error reported in Settings - Update and Security - Activation?

Hi Rick If you originally started with Windows 7, is there a Windows 7 sticker on the base of your PC or laptop, if that is a laptop, that may be in the battery bayThat sticker should report what edition of Windows should be installed on your PC . . .

I also ran the sfc /scannow command and it told me that there were some issues with files that it wasn't able to fix.Each Method/step below progresses to the next if the first does not fix any corrupted files that are found, etc.Have you read this Microsoft information about repairing corrupt system files and errors?"Use the System File Checker tool to repair missing or corrupted system files"https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/kb/929833_________________________________________________And these eightforums.com Tutorials are very detailed for problems resulting from SFC Scan:"How to Run "SFC /SCANNOW" Command at Boot or in Windows 8 and 8.1"http://www.eightforums.com/tutorials/3047-sfc-scannow-command-run-windows-8-a.htmlRead this Section there in conjunction with the rest of the information they give in above link.   NoteIf SFC could not fix something, then run the command again to see if it may be able to the next time. Sometimes it may take running thesfc /scannow command 3 times restarting the PC after each time to completely fix everything that it's able to.If not, then run the Dism /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth command to repair any component store corruption, Repair-WindowsImage -Online -CheckHealthRepair-WindowsImage -Online -ScanHealthRepair-WindowsImage -Online -RestoreHealthRestart the PC afterwards, and try the sfc /scannow command again.If still not, then try using OPTION ONE above to run the sfc /scannow command at bootIf still not, then you could do a refresh of Windows 8, or run aSystem Restore using a restore point dated before the bad file occured to fix it. You may need to repeat doing a System Restore until you find a older restore point that may work.If still not, then you can use the steps in the TIP box in the OPTION THREE section to manually replace the files that SFC could not fix.

Another thing to look at is system temp.  You say the problem happens when you have heavy loads.  Could it be that your system is overheating?  There are various utilities you can download for free that will help you monitor your system temps..Open your computer case and check to see that air flow isn't blocked by dust bunnies.
